headline: Terrible work life balance, rude and ill mannered people, no management vision
pros: The only pro of working at Nomura India is increased patience while you look for other opportunities.
cons:
1. Nomura's risk middle office at India is the global back office technically. All production support is managed in India leading to US/Europe/Japan workshifts. Most production teams are heavily understaffed with work load of 8-10hr per person per day. The team is supposed to work 365 days, with no consideration for Indian holidays (as there in no backup for India). This essentially leads to terrible work life balance, no mandatory holidays, no sick leaves especially for the analysts. 
2. The senior management at RMO has no vision for the well-being and aspirations of the India staff. All decision making happens outside India. The culture is to squeeze the max out of minimum number of guys. Management is totally unaware of the grassroot problems. 
3. Some people at senior level are straight off rude and into micro-micro management. No proper training of new hires. The culture is to get the new hires do all the manual dirty stuff, while the existing staff keeps the interesting/easy stuff.
4. Systems are outdated and IT support is negligent/irresponsible.

headline: Company to work until retirement
pros:
The best Medical Coverage, Work Culture, Flexibility, these are just a few to name.
Nomura takes good care of employees, like no other company will.
Invests heavily on employee trainings, employee welfare and CSR activities.
This is a company that has a heart, it cares for the employees and so it is a company worth being worked in until retirement (if you are okay with perks that match inflation).
cons:
Poor workflow management tools, IT infrastructure needs a lot of work. The workflow management tools should be improved and almost every process needs to be streamlined (since there are multiple systems and tools for a single product).
The perks and remuneration offered here is one of the lowest among any of the investment banks in the world. But, this reduced pay is offset with various facilities like pick-up and doorstep drop.
Transparency within the team is very rare, this mostly depends on the team and the manager.

headline: Cons overweigh the Pros
pros:

Office transport
Discounted meals in cafeteria
Office infrastructure
cons:
1) A very limited career opportunities
2) Hiring procedure (there's no aptitude test, as a result, some of the hired people have a less IQ and are just not eligible and tend to perform poorly)
(Read the job title well before apply as even a master's degree could land a bachelor's level job)
3) Senior management: are reachable at all the times but not very supportive in providing with better career and growth opportunities, senior management members mostly have a bachelor's degree, not much involvement in resolving team issues.
4) Salary and incentives: Basic/Fixed salary component is very less and the variable part makes up for that, which clearly means that at the time of job switching, one will tend to get a raise on the basic salary. You take a leave and your variable component of salary hampers, less salary offered as per the competition.
5) Work life balance: Less team members and much work makes you sit for more hours everyday, the breaks are usually less or sometimes even no breaks for breakfast/lunch.

headline: A loser with no bonus and being forced to leave due to restructuring
pros:
Brand name to write in resume
Getting paid salary on time
cons:
My story: 

Before joining, I worked in another company and got stable 3 month bonus for the past few years. The base was ok but I was aiming higher, so I was contacted and selected by recruiter.

Nomura offered me a slight higher base but discretionary bonus. I questioned them that the total package (assume 0 bonus) they offered was less than my previous company. HR told me bonus usually 2 month. So I joined the company. 

I joined in Dec and their year end review was in end March  every year. For that year, I had no bonus nor salary increment although HR confirmed me that I was eligible for salary/bonus increment that year. The magic word “discretionary” shut me up.

This year, Nomura is not performing well and lose billions of dollars. The company is undergoing huge revamp and a lot of my colleagues disappeared overnight. After full year service,  I was told my bonus is again 0 due to company performance. 

Right after bonus announcement day, I was called up for a meeting where I was told to go through informal  “performance improvement plan”. The purpose is to “help me familiarise with formal performance improvement plan”. I was shocked but still accepted the challenge trying to work my way out.

This performance plan lasted for only 2 weeks. I was told I failed this plan. It’s advisable for me to leave voluntarily before any “HR action” come in place. 

Am looking for new jobs now but I will never join Nomura, ever. 

For god sake, I was never put into performance improvement plan in my years of service. This company impressed me.

headline: Technical Environment poised with Non-Technical people.
pros:
Stability at Job.

The company has somewhat lost the plot when it comes to imposing discipline. Any employee who walks past the company gates post 8:40AM loses half a day's pay, i.e. 8:42 AM, simply because you misplaced your apartment key and boarded another train, will cost you half a day's salary with many frowns from the management. In front office technologies, the pile of technical debt is so massive, that even the most senior developers don't risk proposing a solution, simply because it will be turned down by the veterans of the system who think its too risky to replace Spreadsheet based systems. 
The pile of promotion candidates is massive - and its so dis-heartening to see your colleagues and juniors attaining senior positions in other firms, while you struggle to tackle the layers of one corporate position. So much for loyalty! People who have joined the firm during Lehman times as fresh college graduates have managed to only attain Associate ranking, whereas their colleagues in Finance or BackOffice are EDs and VPs. 
There is no standard code-review process, one manager writes the code for a new assuming its a single person team. The whole application is running on Global Variables. The production system is still on pre ISO C and there have been "co-ordinated efforts" to replace this for about 10 years now.

headline: Think twice about Nomura....
pros:
- generous pension scheme
- nice office
cons:
Nomuras friendly appearance hides a long list of problems. 

1. Chronic understaffing. This results in very long hours. A 12 hour day is normal, at least it is in ops.

2. The Antiquated systems are completely unsuitable for the volume of work.

3, Manual workarounds are standard, sometimes taking up multiple hours in a day.

4. A blame culture is prevalent.

5. The multiple manual processes lead to re-occurring control problems that are used as a threat to hold over analyst level staff. 

6. Senior and middle management are aggressive and bullying.

7. This aggressive and bullying behaviours also spills over into  lower  management levels.

8. Management, at all levels, are uninterested in tackling the root causes of staff concerns. Despite repeated raising of issues

9. Complete lack of willingness to invest in new systems or adapt current processes.

10. Amateur approach to projects. Late running, over budget, no engagement of a suitable project team. 

11. Lack of systematic approach to training. 

I am an experienced investment banker and I have worked in larger and smaller banks than Nomura for over 8 years. I mention this to show I am not an industry newcomer that struggled to adapt to a banking job.  Nomura is hands down the worst place I have ever worked.

headline: The big (Lehman) experiment failed.
pros: Great new office overlooking the Thames
cons:
Cultures still clash following Lehman take-over.  The Japanese have no respect for the ex Lehman Management (in the words of my Japanese boss "what do they know about our business") and visa versa and this ultimately has led to fractured, ever changing management, poor build out decision making, a hopeless control of costs, and the demise of the Company
Little to no respect for a work life balance.  I worked at Nomura for 16 years and each year I needed/ was expected to work longer hours. By the end, to run my business successfully, my usual day was between 12-14 hours, but often more and I often needed to work weekends too. No recognition for this, just redundancy.
I always accepted the fact that a thoroughly Japanese institution such as Nomura would consider the gaijin second class to Japanese, but really, one could quite easily argue Nomura is institutionally racist. To be fair, they did appoint one gaijin to The Board, to suggest that they weren't. However you would only need to look at the ratio of domestically employed Japanese staff members verses non Japanese (which incl non domestic Japanese) of redundancies made from those working in London since the take over of Lehman. It would read something close to zero: thousands. 
There are so many Cons, but to highlight just one more; the continued policy of rotating Japanese management every 2 to 3 years is seriously not conducive to progression at all.  Simply benefits the Japanese  individuals personal desire to tour around the world. I was constantly having to introduce new Japanese bods to clients. It doesn't go down well at all.
